title: Simplifying the Inequality
text: Subtract $$2x$$ from the left and add $$7$$ from the right to get $$5+7<4x-2x$$.

title: Interval Notation
text: The inequality $$6<x$$ can be written in interval notation by specifying the lower bound first, followed by the upper bound.
speech: The inequality  6 is less than x,  can be written in interval notation by specifying the lower bound first, followed by the upper bound.
pacedSpeech: The inequality   6 is less than x,
can be written in interval notation by specifying the lower bound first, followed by the upper bound.

title: Interval Notation
text: If the bound itself should be included as a valid answer of 'x', meaning it can be equal to that value, then a bracket ("[" or "]") should be used. Otherwise, use a paranthesis ("(" or ")").
speech: If the bound itself should be included as a valid answer of 'x', meaning it can be equal to that value, then a bracket ("[" or "]") should be used. Otherwise, use a paranthesis ("(" or ")").

text: Is the lower bound $$6$$ included as a valid value of 'x' in $$6<x$$?

title: Interval Notation
text: Is the upper bound $$\infty$$ included as a valid value of 'x' in $$6<x$$?

subHints.title: Infinity in Interval Notation
subHints.text: As $$\infty$$ is not a number, it cannot be included as part of a valid value or bound for 'x'.

speech: Is the upper bound , infinity  included as a valid value of 'x' in  6, is less than x ?
